Act1Scene6.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene6.text: This castle hath a pleasant seat. The air Nimbly and sweetly recommends itself Unto our gentle senses.

Act1Scene6.speaker: Banquo
Act1Scene6.text: This guest of summer, The temple-haunting martlet, does approve, Hath made his pendant bed and procreant cradle. I have observed, The air is delicate.
Act1Scene6.translation: The martlet approves by nesting here, I have observed

Act1Scene6.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene6.text: See, see our honored hostess!— The love that follows us sometime is our trouble, Which still we thank as love. thank us for your trouble.

Act1Scene6.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act1Scene6.text: All our service, In every point twice done and then done double, Were poor and single business to contend Against those honors deep and broad wherewith Your Majesty loads our house. For those of old, And the late dignities heaped up to them, We rest your hermits.

Act1Scene6.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene6.text: Where’s the Thane of Cawdor? We coursed him at the heels and had a purpose To be his purveyor; but he rides well, And his great love, hath helped him To his home before us.

Act1Scene6.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act1Scene6.text: Your servants ever Have theirs, themselves, and what is theirs in compt To make their audit at your Highness’ pleasure, Still to return your own.

Act1Scene6.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene6.text: Give me your hand. Conduct me to mine host. We love him highly And shall continue our graces towards him.
